bash.eli5: Bash is like talking to your computer using special words to tell it what to do.
bash.boss: Bash is a Unix shell and scripting language widely used for command-line tasks and automation.
bash.sysadmin: Bash (Bourne Again SHell) is a POSIX-compliant shell with command-line editing, scripting, variables, and control flow.
bash.use_case: Used to write automation scripts for server maintenance and backups.

zsh.eli5: Zsh is like a fancier version of Bash with more helpful tricks.
zsh.boss: Zsh is an extended Unix shell that enhances user productivity with plugins and customization features.
zsh.sysadmin: Zsh supports advanced tab completion, globbing, themes (like Oh My Zsh), and is compatible with Bash scripting.
zsh.use_case: Used as a developer-friendly shell with productivity plugins on macOS and Linux.

fish.eli5: Fish is a super friendly shell that finishes your sentences and makes life easier.
fish.boss: Fish is a user-centric shell with modern features and syntax designed for ease of use.
fish.sysadmin: Fish (Friendly Interactive SHell) includes autosuggestions, syntax highlighting, and human-readable scripting syntax out of the box.
fish.use_case: Used by developers for a fast and user-friendly terminal experience with minimal configuration.

sh.eli5: sh is like the grandparent of all the other shells—simple and gets the job done.
sh.boss: sh is the original Unix shell used to run scripts and execute commands on Unix systems.
sh.sysadmin: sh (Bourne Shell) is a lightweight shell commonly used in minimal environments and for basic scripting.
sh.use_case: Used in minimal containers or POSIX-compliant scripts for wide compatibility.

shell_prompt.eli5: The shell prompt is the blinking spot where your computer waits for you to tell it something.
shell_prompt.boss: The shell prompt is the interface in a terminal where users input commands.
shell_prompt.sysadmin: Shell prompts are customizable strings displayed in interactive shells, often showing user, hostname, or path.
shell_prompt.use_case: Used to input shell commands interactively, such as `ls` or `cd /etc`.

login_shell.eli5: A login shell is the first shell that welcomes you when you log in to your computer.
login_shell.boss: A login shell is the initial shell that sets up your environment when you log into a Unix system.
login_shell.sysadmin: Login shells read startup files like `.bash_profile` or `.zprofile` and initialize environment variables for user sessions.
login_shell.use_case: Used to configure PATH variables and user profiles at login time.

interactive_shell.eli5: An interactive shell is the one you talk to by typing commands and getting instant replies.
interactive_shell.boss: An interactive shell is a command-line interface that accepts user input and displays output immediately.
interactive_shell.sysadmin: Interactive shells respond to user inputs with prompts, tab completion, and command history, typically running in terminals.
interactive_shell.use_case: Used when opening a terminal session to run commands directly.

shell_script.eli5: A shell script is a list of computer chores written down so the shell does them for you.
shell_script.boss: A shell script is a file containing a series of shell commands that automate tasks.
shell_script.sysadmin: Shell scripts use scripting languages like Bash to execute sequences of commands, logic, and file operations automatically.
shell_script.use_case: Used to back up logs or restart services on a scheduled basis.

command_line.eli5: The command line is a place where you type instructions to tell your computer what to do.
command_line.boss: The command line is a text-based interface used to run programs and manage systems.
command_line.sysadmin: The command line interface (CLI) processes textual input to execute commands, offering more control and scripting than GUIs.
command_line.use_case: Used to manage servers, install packages, and automate tasks.

cli_command_line_interface.eli5: CLI is like texting your computer instructions instead of clicking buttons.
cli_command_line_interface.boss: CLI stands for Command Line Interface, which lets users control systems via typed commands.
cli_command_line_interface.sysadmin: The CLI allows direct interaction with the OS or apps using commands, flags, and scripts for powerful automation and precision.
cli_command_line_interface.use_case: Used to deploy apps, configure networks, or run diagnostics quickly.
